Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SG: The evolution of transposable element silencing mechanisms in the absence of transposable elements
Award.AbstractNarration:
Transposable elements (TEs) are DNA sequences with the ability to move and make copies in a genome through -cut and paste- or -copy and paste- mechanisms. TEs are major components of vertebrate genomes, and account for at least 45% of the human genome. Because the unrestricted proliferation of TEs can have profound, and mostly deleterious, biological effects, the question of how organisms control TE mobilization has attracted high interest. Experimental data suggest that TEs and a recently discovered class of small non-coding RNAs called piRNAs, are involved in an evolutionary arms race, similar to that of pathogens and the immune system. Briefly, piRNAs direct proteins against TE derived messenger RNAs. However, the details of the interplay between piRNAs and TEs are far from clear. The research objective of this project is to characterize piRNA repertoires in the ground squirrel, which lacks ongoing TE activity, by contrasting them with mouse which have ongoing TE activity.

Understanding how genomes protect themselves from the challenges presented by TE invasion is a fundamental question in evolutionary genomics. This project represents a step in that direction. TEs have the ability to change genes and their expression, and as such they can have profound biological effects. In addition, the piRNA pathway has enormous potential for applications in biotechology and medicine. If the investigators are able to direct this pathway, they should be able to target deleterious gene variants, such as those involved in cancer, and this project will contribute towards this long term objective. In addition, this project will permit the training of young researchers in bioinformatics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transposable elements (TEs) are genetic elements with the ability to mobilize in the genome of their host through “cut and paste” or “copy and paste” mechanisms. Because of their ability to hijack the cellular machinery of the host to insert additional copies of themselves in the genome, TEs are considered genetic parasites. They are major components of eukaryotic genomes and, in the case of mammals, ~50% of the genome sequence is derived from TEs.


The ability of TEs to mobilize makes them powerful mutagens at two levels.  First, the act of inserting new copies into a genome has the potential to influence gene expression via the introduction of novel regulatory elements, disruption exons and splice junctions, and exon shuffling. However, TEs need not be actively mobilizing to have an effect on genome structure and evolution.  Post-insertion TE-mediated rearrangements through non-homologous recombination are well-documented, and large genomic deletions, duplications, inversions, translocations and chromosome breaks have all been linked to the presence of TEs in a variety of genomes.


Although a small number of TE insertions have been identified as adaptive, TE activity is generally considered a serious challenge to genome integrity. Thus, it is not surprising the eukaryotes have evolved mechanisms to restrict their mobilization, especially in the germline. piRNAs are a recently discovered class of small RNAs found in animal genomes that play a key role in protecting the genome against TE proliferation. Briefly, piRNAs and PIWI/Argonaute proteins assemble into complexes that target TE-like sequences via base complementarity to the piRNAs, where new piRNAs are generated by degrading TEs. As currently understood, piRNAs in play a role similar to that of the antibodies in the immune system, but at the nucleotide sequence level: to distinguish self from non-self at the sequence level and target the latter for degradation. Because the set of TEs active in a given species changes over time and novel TEs can invade a genome from another species, the relationship between TEs and piRNAs is expected to resemble the evolutionary arms race between pathogens and the immune system. As is the case with most parasites, the set of TEs challenging a particular host changes over time.


Our project focused on exploring the evolutionary relationships between piRNAs and TEs with a focus on the ground squirrel, a species where TE insertion rates have been greatly reduced in the last 5 million years. In other words, we wanted to know what the cellular reaction would be to a cessation of TE activity and accumulation. We did this by comparing patterns of piRNA and PIWI protein expression in the squirrel with rabbit and mouse, two species with known patterns of recent TE accumulation. In most cases, we found that the abundance of TEs and the corresponding piRNAs is correlated. In simpler terms, our results suggest that to a certain extent, the piRNA defense system is able to modulate its response to target the most challenging TEs. In addition, we found major differences in how PIWI proteins are expressed in the squirrel relative to any other mammal analyzed up to now. It is unclear at this point whether this change in expression is a result of TE quiescence or a factor in inducing that quiescence. Finally, our studies suggest that TEs contribute to piRNA repertoires even in the absence of detectable TE mobilization. Together these results improve our understanding of the interactions between cellular defenses and the parasites they defend against.


Through this funding, we were able to support three graduate students and multiple undergraduate researchers. The funding contributed directly to two terminal degrees thus far, a PhD and an MS. Two manuscripts directly related to the study topic were produced and several others benefited.
